(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Many people who lost everything in the recent floods in Louisiana are veterans of disaster.
After Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans 11 years ago, thousands of the city's residents moved to Baton Rouge to try to rebuild their lives.
Eve Troeh of member station WWNO in New Orleans met one woman who has to start over yet again.
Myra Engrum isn't ready to start another day mucking out her flooded home - not just yet.
And there's no place to sit.
So we go to McDonald's.
The parking lot's full of cars with insurance company logos, lots of construction trucks, too.
A lot of meetings are happening here.
Inside, Engrum spreads out her paperwork.
Her curly, dark hair peeks out from under a khaki baseball cap.
She reapplies pink lipstick - a sort of armor of civility against the chaos.
I had over four and a half feet of water in my home.
And this is my first home that I've ever purchased.
I got the home right after Katrina.
She lost everything after that storm.
She moved here to start a new life.
It was wonderful to just feel like I would never have to be homeless again.
That was my big deal.
We're going to get a home, so we're not homeless again.
We was Engrum and her pregnant daughter.
Her daughter died soon after childbirth.
Myra Engrum became the baby's mother.
Jeremiah is now 10.
She's 61.
The two of them were in their small, brick ranch house when the flood came.
And I call him my hero.
We were in the living room, and he peeked through a mail slot.
And he said, Mommy, there's water in the street.
They drove out just in time.
That night, around midnight, Engrum sat in her car with her son in the dark.
And something clicked.
Her disaster experience from a decade ago kicked into gear.
All of a sudden, I said, Jeremiah, do you have a tablet?
I need a tablet to write on.
I've got to make some notes.
Her son pulled a notebook from his backpack.
Now it's on the McDonald's table, full of lists, phone numbers, names of FEMA reps and insurance agents.
From my experience with Katrina, I knew that people are going to be asking things, like, you know, what did you lose in the house?
I wonder if the rain's going to affect their work today.
Dark clouds loom as she meets the contractor at her house on Acacia Street.
So what are we going to - what are you ready to do now?
We're going to open the door and finish doing - I got to get your appliances out.
So I got to tear that kitchen out.
OK, all right.
Engrum had taken the precaution of buying flood insurance.
But it only pays for home repairs.
She couldn't afford the more expensive policy to cover contents, like furniture and appliances - the stuff that's now piled in a mountain out front.
That's everything I owned - pots and pans, cabinets, you name it, mattresses, Jeremiah's camping stuff, his Boy Scouts uniform.
Engrum won't let Jeremiah see the house.
Health officials want kids to stay away from moldy homes and slippery debris.
Plus, she worries it's traumatic.
For now, they're staying with one of Jeremiah's former teachers, an hour's drive away.
Each day, Engrum makes the trip to Baton Rouge to drop her son at day camp while she deals with house stuff.
She stops in to check on him.
And just a minute - oh, you're all sweaty.
This is Ms. E...
It's hard to tell if he understands the extent of what's been lost.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Coming up, the bad economy isn't bad for everyone.
Investors are buying up U.S.
dollars.
They're making a comeback.
But first, the economy is bad for General Motors.
The company's auditors say there is substantial doubt GM can survive.
It has until the end of this month to present its restructuring plans in order to receive $30 billion in additional aid from the federal government.
Without that money, GM says it will go bankrupt.
Micheline Maynard covers the auto industry for the New York Times, and she joins us now.
And Micheline, what is the likelihood GM will receive this additional $30 billion and survive?
Well, it's something that's being debated as we speak.
General Motors officials and others were scheduled to meet today with the Auto Panel.
It's a group of officials that President Obama has put together to look at this very subject, whether General Motors and Chrysler deserve to get more assistance from the government.
So, if they say yes, GM can receive this money.
Does that mean it's out of the woods or could it still declare bankruptcy?
It actually doesn't, and General Motors did a securities filing today with the SEC.
And in it, it said that even if it gets federal assistance that auto market is so bad, that a further deterioration in the car market could also drive it into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
So, even with all of this federal money, it could just still go out of business?
No, no. And people misunderstand Chapter 11.
It's an opportunity to reorganize under court protection, and a lot of the airlines went through it.
I covered a lot of those cases for the New York Times.
And it really does give you an opportunity to shed unprofitable parts of your business and get going again.
The only problem is a lot of times you see labor contracts go into the chopper.
They - the workers end up with sharply lower benefits and pay.
And suppliers may not make out very well.
Dealers may not make out very well.
So, GM has been warning that this is a very dire prospect that they'd like to avoid.
